snippet.textDisplay:
IMHO, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a good game, but it has a few quality of life issues that ruins the whole experience for me. 
First, the game doesn't have a fast travel option, so there is a lot of back tracking between biomes. Second, there is no mini-map,  world map, or quest markers, to point  you in the right direction. Needless to say, running around in a biome, completely lost, and fighting the same enemies that respawn once you use a save point gets old real fast. Lastly, the level bosses are seriously OP, and some fights will take over 30 minutes to play out, and hopefully you dont die and have to restart. 
The game does have some great moments, but I don't have the patience to finish it.

snippet.textDisplay: if anybody is here wondering if this game is worth it, i am here too say that it is indeed worth it if you like a compelling story fantasy/sy-fi adventure game. this is it. its mainly following a path to get what you need to be. though the range in how to get there is somewhat roomy. the combat is mucch like final fantasy-ish in the way that you can either attack, or do spells, items...etc. ....but while the enemies are attacking you, you can in real time either dodge or perry the attack if you time it right. I love adventure story driven games, such as visions of mana, uncharted, the last of us, until dawn, days gone...etc and this is pretty good as well. they did so much to make this game so beautiful, but my only gripe so far, is the facial animations are kinda bland compared to how rendered the faces look than the actual lip movements. the lip movement needs some work for sure. but it's still a great game. and would look forward to this game if there is a seccond one in the future.

snippet.textDisplay:
Expedition 33 isn't just a game. It transcends what we know as video games. It excelled in every aspect, graphics, level design, art direction, music (can't believe composer is 25 years old and it's his first professional work), the story, voice acting, combat, gameplay.... just every aspect of it. It is without a doubt GOTY. But what transcends it beyond is this game not only is a piece of modern art, but it is a statement. The game released at a fraction of what triple A games release for and during the first week of release, they discounted it! They also released everything for the game on day one like the OST for everyone to enjoy. There's NO microtransactions or content blocking behind a paywall. The game performed phenomenally on release with pretty much zero performance issue. It was developed by a core dev team of 30 ish people (outsourced to 3rd party for extra stuff so technically more than 30). In a world littered with garbage games that has been in the rinse and repeat cycle with a cost of $70-90 dollars with multiple paid DLC, battlepass, microtransactions, etc... this game gave the player base EVERYTHING for AFFORDABLE and REASONABLE price. To be frank, knowing what I know now, this game is EASILY $80-90.... I would gladly pay that to play this masterpiece. 
I have no doubt that Expedition 33 breathed life back into a dying industry and revived the love for gaming in many gamers. 
The ONLY con I have for this game... no other game feels worth it now that I've completed Expedition 33... everything else is so meh....

snippet.textDisplay:
When this game wins the Game of the Year award, it will show other developers what is truly important to players. It will show that a work created for the love of art, for the love of beauty, will always find its consumer. That the tactics of greedy publishers will sooner or later disappear into oblivion, and the industry will heal.
Games like this will heal the industry. For those who come after.

snippet.textDisplay: After buying this game a few days ago, here's my short and personal review. 9.5 out of 10. I'd give it a 10, but there are some very minor inconveniences. The gaming industry needs to take a lesson from this independent studio for its originality and, more specifically, (this is directed at you square enix) for returning the turn based RPG back to its former glory. It gives me FFX vibes with Mario RPG gameplay with the timed dodges and attacks both of those games created by whom? Square Enix. Square, go back to your roots!

snippet.textDisplay:
Sorry, this is one of the worst RPGs I've ever seen. If it weren't for the graphics, it's be forgotten in a week. 
   Unbalanced to all atrocious hell, nothing in the whole RPG mechanic of this game matters, no stats, no skills, no weapons. 
  This game forces you to depend 100% on a Parry/Dodge effect lest you have your team often wiped out in one hit. It's pointless. Long dreary drawn out game with the prettiest, but most basic yet also difficult environments to transverse.
   Great effort here, but with broken rpg mechanics, and with a story progression that could be slaughtered by SNES game.
  I give this a flat 8 at best
snippet.textOriginal:
Sorry, this is one of the worst RPGs I've ever seen. If it weren't for the graphics, it's be forgotten in a week.

   Great effort here, but with broken rpg mechanics, and with a story progression that could be slaughtered by SNES game.
  I give this a flat 8 at best

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish the last act in Expedition33 wasn't about an addicted child's fight with her father, but was related to the world of the map. Because in the beginning you get a completely different plot connected with this beautiful and interesting world, and at the end the plot is about something else. You get a dissonance. I came to play one thing - and at the end of the other in terms of the story :(

I would dream of a ‘clean ending’ - where they ‘clean up’ everything unnecessary at the canvas, returning it to what it was - without the creations of his mother and father, without Maelle and the split, without the whole generation of people (including Gustave and the others). That is, to a state where only the interesting and bizarre creatures created by Verso live. And the canvas itself is sent under the lock of a safe with no way to get there. Isn't it a sorrowful and sad ending, which, nevertheless, is not reduced to a banal addiction to the virtual world, but teaches to appreciate and not to interfere in other people's creations, even if it can temporarily help with the grief of loss?

snippet.textDisplay:
Possibly the most frustrating game ive ever played. The storyline is incredible but heartbreaking.... the visual and sound is unreal.

But the mechanics, the appearance of open world and the difficulty..... its not any kind of open world if during the main story you stumble onto a side quest that asks you to go somewhere in an open world style.... in which the normal mobs will 1 shoot you... and this didnt just happen once, or twice or three times in my 18 hrs playing!!

If you're new to modern final fantasy style... just give this a skip. You'll thank me later

snippet.textDisplay: I just beat it, it was a great game.  It has beautiful graphics.  Fantastic music.  They story is compelling, if a little over-complex at times, and it has great characters that you care about so you'll want to know what happens next.  The battle system is fun and challenging, if you played mario rpgs and legend of dragoon, you'll know what to expect.  Only few complains I have is that the game is short, it only took me 20 hours to beat, which by RPG standards is not very long.  Doesn't have any towns or cities aside from maybe two.  Some enemies annoy me for how often they attack more than once.  Easily my favorite game this year so far.
snippet.textOriginal: I just beat it, it was a great game.  It has beautiful graphics.  Fantastic music.  They story is compelling, if a little over-complex at times, and it has great characters that you care about so you'll want to know what happens next.  The battle system is fun and challenging, if you played mario rpgs and legend of dragoon, you'll know what to expect.  Only few complains I have is that the game is short, it only took me 20 hours to beat, which by RPG standards is not very long.  Doesn't have any towns or cities aside from maybe two. One of the best games I've played in a long time. The graphics, fight scenes and cinematics are often epic tier. Music is borderline epic tier. A great game for anyone who enjoys the genre, but outstanding for completionists like me always checking every corner for hidden loot and seeing what Devs may have hidden in some random spot. Highly rewarding. Constantly triggering the dopamine. 

A must play.

Let me be clear: 

We shouldn’t be saying “wow how did a studio of only 30 make such a great game!”

We should be saying “why can’t a company of thousands not produce a game half as good?”

A small passionate team is going to always produce a more quality product than a soulless design-by-committee game.

snippet.textDisplay:
The best way to understand turn-based RPGs is to think of it through the lens of playing a trading card game like Magic the Gathering. Clair Obscur deploys this concept masterfully. Each battle feels like you’re playing a new game of Magic with your favorite deck.

So the shift to action combat in series like Final Fantasy is not a “natural progression.” The former gameplay style was not that way due to “technical limitations.” It’s a change, not an evolution.

You may like it or hate it, but turn-based is just a different equally compelling way to play, and a few games recently have already proven that it can work very well with modern high-production aesthetics and expectations. Clair Obscur simply nailed that coffin shut for good, and I’m so glad it did.

Square Enix, I hope you’re ready now to retract the demonstrably false claim that turn-based with realistic graphics don’t fit.
snippet.textOriginal:
The best way to understand turn-based RPGs is to think of it through the lens of playing a trading card game like Magic the Gathering. Clair Obscur deploys this concept masterfully. Each battle feels like you’re playing a new game of Magic with your favorite deck.

So the shift to action combat in series like Final Fantasy is not a “natural progression.” The former gameplay style was not that way due to “technical limitations.” It’s a change, not an evolution.

You may like it or hate it, but turn-based is just a different equally compelling way to play, and a few games recently have already proven that it can work very well with modern high-production aesthetics and expectations. Clair Obscur simply nailed that coffin shut for good, and I’m so glad it did.

Square Enix, I hope you’re ready now to retract the demonstrably false claim that turn-based with realistic graphics don’t fit.

snippet.textDisplay:
Let me get straight to the point—I don’t recommend this game at the moment.
First, the combat system is a mess. While incorporating QTEs into a turn-based game is a fresh idea, the blocking window is extremely tight even on normal difficulty. Most enemies also use delayed attacks and combos, forcing players to memorize every move of every enemy, which significantly increases frustration.
Second, the map guidance is terrible. There’s no minimap, and your companions provide zero direction during exploration, making it very easy to get lost.
snippet.textOriginal:

Second, the map guidance is terrible. There’s no minimap, and your companions provide zero direction during exploration, making it very easy to get lost.

This might be the single best game I've played in such a long time. This was a story that wanted to be told. The developers and writers have my appreciation. You let the story and characters tell their own story and didn't wrestle it into submission like so many people do now. Great writer once said. The characters and ideas want to tell their own story, and if you respect them, they will tell it. 
This was a story and characters I won't soon forget.
Thank you, developers.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is an absolute masterpiece. I cannot understate this. It truly is. 

1. The story is focused and engaging. With twists and turns that will keep you tuned in. 
2. The combat system is addicting, fluid, skillful, and very customizable. 
3. The world is beautiful. Each area is vastly different from the other. The enemies are varied significantly. 
4. The characters are so nuanced and you grow to care for them immensely. 
5. The price is that of a AA game. but this is truly a magnum opus experience in turn based RPG's. It's a AAA. A real AAA. 
6. The pace of the story is perfect. No wasted time. No endless grind. 
7. The game doesn't hold your hand, but it isn't brutally hard either. It is in perfect balance. 
8. This is the first time I don't even want to blast through the game. I am truly enjoying every minute of it and don't want it to end. 
9. THE MUSIC. 

Just an opinion. Make your own decisions gamers.

snippet.textDisplay:
Observation: I’m looking forward to playing the game on Steam Deck, but I think some of the praise it’s receiving may be influenced by its French origins. It raises the question of whether a game with similar quality, but set in a different cultural context—such as an African country—would receive the same level of attention. The art direction and enemy designs are impressive, and the game appears to be well-made overall.

That said, media influence and early impressions seem to shape public perception significantly. For example, South of Midnight received a more mixed response, despite also offering strong themes, music, lore, and voice acting. While Expedition 33 has more polished combat, both games offer different styles and deserve fair consideration. It’s important to recognize how factors like setting, cultural background, and representation may impact how games are received.

snippet.textDisplay:
This game is awesome! I know there has been a shadow drop which is all the rage these days but I cannot pass on a game with a lot of heart and soul in it, made by a new studio. It caught my eye from the first trailer and here I am supporting it. I am on the first Act and all I can say is WOW. Also I have to say it has to be the gateway drug to turn-based games because (from a non turn based games player) it doesn't feel like the action really stops even though ofc it does; you get sucked into the strategies your brain can concoct then you watch your plan play out and if things go as intended is like having a brain-gasm 😂 OH it performs well with the hardware of the last years and looks like the wife/husband of your dreams 💪
Well done Sandfall Interactive!

snippet.textDisplay: Video game fanatic here; this is by far the best game ( in today’s standards) that isn’t a remaster , isn’t a cash grab, isn’t a unnecessary game that no one wants(ed). Here we get : expedition 33, a beautiful graphically alls well game that is by far better than most game industries games that have more than enough people to create a great game as opposed to this one that was/is a small studio. Kudos to this studio for bringing fire to our generation. More games need to be like this; new ip or a game that is ACTUALLY FINISHED. Not only is this game great but they brought back the price point for the game( back in the day when games were 50/60 dollars.

snippet.textDisplay: The game looks VERY good and I can't wait to try it out, but it feels like they've leaned a bit too much into their style at times. The bestiary/bosses/monsters looks quite bland and all of them seem to follow a pretty boring aesthetic/artstyle. I hope I'm wrong and I'm just basing this off what I've seen in videos. But for a game that is essentially taking a lot of JRPG elements, I was hoping the absolute wild and at times over the top bosses, would be one of them.

snippet.textDisplay:
I REALLY love the way they have integrated the open world, so reminiscent of the  FF of old. It brought an air of adventure and mystery to those FF once you were out in it.
I remember that open world in FFVII FFVIII and FFIX, and I have missed it since FFX onwards. I thought that it couldn't be made because graphics would take a hit,  but this game  proves otherwise.
Same goes for turn-based battles. An amazing implementation.
Well done to this studio!!!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I like the idea of interviewing the reviewer. With big publications it's often easy to forget the reviews are written by an individual with their own tastes and biases, not 'IGN' as whole. Getting a glimpse into what those tastes are gives some useful context.  

As for the game itself it looks awesome, you love to see a new developer knock it out of the park on their first attempt. Can't wait to see what's next for them
